subject_prompt_600:
Sami Michael is an example of a citizen being subjected to the provisions of the Directive and the laws concerning hate speech. For this reason, his work is protected by the right of free expression. It is therefore the objective of the Committee to investigate the case and submit its report by 15 June 2013 in order to draw public attention to such cases, as well as to protect the rights of citizens, especially the right to freedom of expression and freedom of thought and conscience. The Committee also expects the government to do its best to amend these and other statutes that may not be compatible with the Directive or the laws on hate speech. In particular, the law on hate speech should be amended to include more precise definitions of terms such as "hate speech," "national origin," "race," "religion" or "ethnicity."

Contact:

Citizens' Committee for the Protection of Human Rights (CCPHR)

http://www.ccpr.be
coupled_prompt_600:
HCJ 5555/18

Henceforth, I shall call you "Sam" and "Mike."

Sam Michael, and myself, are part of a group of people in our area who find themselves with the same "problem," or "condition." We are also aware that this is the case for a number of other people in other communities. We know we need help. If you have the resources, please assist us!

If this sounds interesting to you, please contact me at my email address below.

Mike Pyle

[email protected]


A Brief Synopsis of HCJ 5555/18

The Problem

I am Sam Michael. At some point in my life (I don't remember exactly), I developed a condition called HCM. When people ask me about it, I usually tell them about how I was diagnosed by a doctor of my choice, and told how it would take three months of intensive therapy to get rid of it. This story makes no sense, so let's try to put it into words.

I remember being diagnosed with HCM (Hemorrhagic Myopathy) in 1991, when I was about 25 years old. I spent two weeks in the hospital recovering from my wounds (the first time ever in my life). The doctors believed they had found an abscess on my heart valve, and that if I didn't correct it, I could die. The rest of my family thought this sounded crazy too, as they were used to the idea that I might never run out of breath and die a slow death. As it turned out, it wasn't true — but it was a lot better than not having any oxygen at all.

During those two weeks, I was completely unable to exercise or walk without intense pain. I couldn't even take a shower without feeling like I was cutting off my circulation. No matter what the doctors said I should do, or where they'd take me, there was always this pain. It felt awful to think that I would eventually suffer this condition for the rest of my life.

My symptoms lasted approximately one year. During that entire year, I tried to convince everyone else I knew about the problem. I tried to tell them everything I could to no avail. Everyone tried to tell me it wouldn't happen to me because I'm an athlete, or my blood type is A+ (they couldn't see the problem there either). They told me I could avoid the disease by quitting the exercise habit. I told them that would only make the situation worse. Instead of telling me what to do, they instead gave me various diet advice: eat more protein; avoid salt, sugar and red meat; avoid dairy; avoid alcohol; etc.

After I recovered from the initial shock of being diagnosed and treated for HCM, I immediately set out to research anything that would explain the condition. For several years, I followed every diet, drug, exercise regime
